Most of the basic words we use can't be accurately captured in a single, succinct definition. The boundaries are extremely fuzzy, and when forced to supply our own rigorous definition, we'll probably say something inaccurately or miss a bunch of edge-cases that intuitively belong but were excluded from our definition (or vice-versa). ''In nearly all practical situations, it's not necessary to have an ironclad definition to get by in the world and make reasonable judgments. We interpret the meaning of words based on context and act accordingly, being as broad or as specific as needed for the task at hand, and typically only focused on a few aspects as pertinent and ignoring the rest.

There's nothing wrong with defining a word for the sake of a discussion. Oftentimes words have multiple meanings or have meanings that have been misconstrued by culture that have completely lost their true meaning. Think of the word socialism for example. Socialism no longer means what it technically means to the average person. When the average (U.S.) person hears or reads the word socialism, they're more likely to think of the country's who have implemented socialism, like the USSR and Venzuela, and how it's a generally bad thing that results in a dictatorship. What socialism truly means is an economic system in which the means of production is socialized. It's important that we define words that have ambigious meanings because often times many words have multiple meanings to different people, and if we dont set out a clear defintion pf the term, any discussion regarding that term will be futile. What Knowles did was not bad faith at all.

As an example of why pinning down a specific definition is difficult/foolish/pointless:''Consider two hypothetical court cases. In the first, someone is fired and alleges that they were terminated on grounds of sexism and misogyny. So whether or not they were a woman would be extremely relevant in that case, and would revolve around social cues, like how they look, acted, and behaved, and the case would turn on how the employer acted based on those things. Even if you believe yourself to be a man and that you look, act and behave like a stereotypical man, if your boss nonetheless believes that you are a woman and fires you solely on that basis, then they are in violation of anti-discrimination statutes and will likely lose their case.''An alternative: there is a pharmaceutical diagnostics company that makes a sophisticated test to detect diseases. Some diseases appear more frequently in one gender or another, a gender being defined as a specific grouping of biochemical markers and traits. A patient is misdiagnosed by this test, is given a treatment that they didn't need, which caused side effects of which they died. From my understanding the only legal definitions in the justice system are for the procedural functionality of that said system (writ, tort, statute, subpoena, party, hearsay, docket, etc). Any other terms (eg 'women') that relate to written laws (eg title IX) are either defined in those pieces of legislation or undefined, which is when the art of litigation takes place to debate the interpretation, intent, and application of stated law(s) for a particular case scenario. So to answer the broad question, what is a woman? You need both context and a scenario. What is a woman in relation to the survival of the human race and our reproductive ability? What is a woman in relation it's significance of being in love with another person? What is a woman in relation a school's fulfillment of Title IX? The short form question is too simple to adequately answer because 'woman' has many definitions that are dependent on a particular scenario. It does make for a useful political tool because it seems like it should be easy ? to answer but in the context of law and one's qualifications to be a judge, it's is a very poorly worded question (if your intent is to actually discuss the topic vs generate political responses)

If you can't agree on the definitions of words or at least stipulate which definition you will be using in the course of a discussion, then all discourse falls apart. To say that he only discusses politics and won't agree to stipulate the definitions of the terms he's using is a bad faith move.  If womanhood is the issue being discussed, as with transgendered folks in women's sports, then a definition of what a woman is becomes crucial. I ask myself, which side of an issue benefits from keeping a cloud over a term or concept, and that's the side you need to pin down on clarity the most. The down side of politics being everywhere in the media is that everyone, including most commenting, think they should play politics.  There was a time when defining what being a 'citizen' meant was quite relevant to a lot of people in this country. Words and their meanings are old and come from the limited observation of past groups of people.  Sometimes they are vague, and sometimes they can be extremely specific. The problem arises when societies and it´s views on categories change, as well as when, with the growth of the population, more and more different statistical events start to become more apparent, one of them being infertility/not producing eggs (the specialized cells). So now it´s no longer that a woman is someone who has eggs and can have a baby (in the case of someone with Turner´s not only are they more likely than not to be infertile, but they don´t even have that many of the secondary sexual characteristics associated to women. Many a times will have small breats, not having that much of a curvy body, etc). Plus, not always is a woman interested in having kids. But beyond that, when science becomes a thing and it also progresses and discovers new things, it also becomes a force that leads to changes in society. In this case, it is no longer valid to say that men are (exclusively) XY and women XX (although it is the main sex differentiation system for mammals. other animals from different groups work differently, some not even having sexual chromosomes). It was discovered that the man/male part only arises if a specific gene, which is present (most of the time) in the XY chromosome, the SRY gene, is there and is functioning. So now, we don´t exactly know what is a man nor a woman just by using a single or few things to back it up. Then we have genetic alterations, affecting the number of chromosomes (duplicating or deleting whole ones or stitching together broken parts of other chromosomes into a single one, resulting in having an extra...), which can also affect sexual cormosomes (XXX, XXY, XYY, X0, etc), leading to 'men who are women' and 'women who are men', and I´m not even talking about transexual and intersex/hermaphrodite people here (there´s also the hormonal and physiological aspect of it, not just the chromosomes)... So human sex has always been a messy thing, but it just wasn´t perceived like this before (although, different societies many times also had something akin to a third sex, or something else entirely...). I´d say that human (chromosomal) sex (de facto, taking into account all these things i´ve mentioned) is more like islands. There are different kinds, and some may looks just like others. It´s (to me) not a spectrum, because you can´t directly change your (human) sexual chromosomes at a will nor through other methods, but it´s also not something binary, black and white, set in stone. And if you really want to see something crazy, I recommend you search up (genetic) chimerism/chimeras and mosaicism in humans (and other animals if you feel like it)... So yeah, not easy, but something in the law is gonna have to change, and/or the definition of a word will have to.

Here, IMO, my position in what I'd say would reflect from this POV to convey (although this is just a stream of consciousness not applicable to a talk-show quick-talk; more like it's him and I sitting at a coffee house or bar with time to kill):''Well, what is a woman vs not -- that is (also) dependent on age, in our language and conception.  Woman vs a girl on the basis of one's sex -- where 'biologically' it happens in-between junior high and high school for the most part.  Some will say not until you're 18.  Or, maybe 'fully' a woman, or man, at 21?  The definition on just this front is a bit relative.  Nobody's going to say a 2 year old's a woman, nobody's going to say you have to be 60 to be a woman.  But there is a relative 'line' between girl ' woman when their sex as a female is quite clear, and going on a biological scale or even outside of that if you wanted to get more exact, it'd be on a person-by-person basis -- not Everyone as a whole.  But there is a 'line' for everyone as a whole when it comes to legal matters, for the sake of functionality of the people.  This may sound moot at first glance, but this is to point out how things are Not 'necessarily' black and white.  You asked me to define a woman after all -- and honestly, that haziness 'line' would have to be addressed, outside a current legally-defined one.''For over 99% of the people, whether you're male or female, as in one's sex -- that has no haziness or argument, fitting any definition of male or female, broad or technical.  But not 100%, even on just one's sex.  As a key example, there are a few who are born with two DNAs, one of them clearly representing male, and one of female -- and they vary in what's produced.  What say you there?  We both would be arguing 'IF' we had to choose just ONE sex for each ONE individual of this variety (as they vary), and with some, we'd totally agree IF we had to play that board game, so to speak.  And we Both would take their overall gender (different than sex) as a person into account if they're grown up, into forming our board game positions.  So that is a hazy, albeit very small, zone on one's sex alone.  OK, you may say -- but that's a super small fraction of 1%.  Well, the point is, we can agree that's a Super small fraction, and not 100%.  There In Fact does exist a very thin line on that front where it's Literally ' Factually, not fitting any clear definition of even one's sex, let alone gender.''But is that the ONLY determining point, the DNA, on one's sex as far as what's formed as a person?  After all, the development of a being is analog, not digital.  Would we be shocked, accepting the concept of the above in mind, that there are other, albeit slim, potential caveats?  I wouldn't think so -- but that's for scientific research ' knowledge to put into play, and cases about exactly this topic depend on.  So no pre-judging here, if you catch my drift, depending on case -- even though, yes, for over 99% of the population, it's a cut and dry identifier that's fitting and uncontroversial.''And I think the above is where Gender is put into play.   As I think it'd be quite safe to assume that has more leeway than a genetic-purposes identifier.  As you could be clearly of the female sex, yet, your construct is observable from outsiders it ain't so clear.  I mean, I think given enough years in life, most of us have observed someone in the room while thinking 'Is that a dude?  Or a gal?  Shoot, wait, I'm thinking ... no, actually... hold on, I need a much better look,' while said person is projecting themselves as of any 'transexual' of any kind, but instead pretty gender neutral but in whatever fashion wear that's the norm.  And that's not by behavior, that's just what they Look like.  So obviously in the complexities within people's wiring, where there can be assumptions thrown off about them IF we analyze them as a person, etc -- things aren't always going to be black and white, even when it comes to basic concepts where for 99% of the population it is.  So could someone be/feel as the other sex that they clearly are not, when that part as usual is of no argument -- without having some mental issues being the cause?''From a biological perspective (DNA, vagina, ovaries, breasts; even if the latter 3 may not be well formed), even it's Almost always quite clear whether one's a woman, and not a man or anything in-between.  But from a by-product Being of said DNA forming them and their 'wiring' and not just in their personal, mental identification (which it's not reliant on technically; just as some people think they're straight when they're not, as one analogy) -- that has a more widened thin gap compared to biological sex.  To what degree?  I dunno, but that's moot.  Just that it can be.  I don't think one's apparent/claimed mentality in the present should = their actual gender.  But like that one person where you're like 'Is that a dude or a gal?' and having to analyze them, still being stumped and not betting the farm on your final but at least somewhat hazy conclusion -- one's gender can be different than what their DNA marker ' inner 'parts down there' may say.

Sex Redefined: The Idea of 2 Sexes Is Overly Simplistic''As a clinical geneticist, Paul James is accustomed to discussing some of the most delicate issues with his patients. But in early 2010, he found himself having a particularly awkward conversation about sex.'A 46-year-old pregnant woman had visited his clinic at the Royal Melbourne Hospital in Australia to hear the results of an amniocentesis test to screen her baby's chromosomes for abnormalities. The baby was fine—but follow-up tests had revealed something astonishing about the mother. Her body was built of cells from two individuals, probably from twin embryos that had merged in her own mother's womb. And there was more. One set of cells carried two X chromosomes, the complement that typically makes a person female; the other had an X and a Y. Halfway through her fifth decade and pregnant with her third child, the woman learned for the first time that a large part of her body was chromosomally male. “That's kind of science-fiction material for someone who just came in for an amniocentesis,” says James.'Sex can be much more complicated than it at first seems. According to the simple scenario, the presence or absence of a Y chromosome is what counts: with it, you are male, and without it, you are female. But doctors have long known that some people straddle the boundary—their sex chromosomes say one thing, but their gonads (ovaries or testes) or sexual anatomy say another. Parents of children with these kinds of conditions—known as intersex conditions, or differences or disorders of sex development (DSDs)—often face difficult decisions about whether to bring up their child as a boy or a girl. Some researchers now say that as many as 1 person in 100 has some form of DSD.''Could you be a Chimera?'''https://youtu.be/8WsF9Z4B7T8">https://youtu.be/8WsF9Z4B7T8'

As an academic, I do define words, and in a different way to the dictionary ones. There's of course a role for definitions but like was suggested for 'love', there is a total inadequacy of using the dictionary definition to somehow capture a concept in all its parameters and sense and uses and so on. The dictionary is used as a part of definition, and even two dictionaries, particularly a dictionary for the lay population and the ones that biologists or other specialists use are wholly different. And definitions used in academia are always tentative, open to change in the light of new insights. Before we know about chromosomes, definitions of women do not include XX verses XY forms, which are realistically the closest the definition gets in modern biology that normally comes up in discussions, and that use has problems anyway, when the expression of the genes on the chromosomes give rise to hermaphroditic people. In such cases, the person where sex is interminate is decided, by judgement, to fill a box on a birth certificates in many countries, since they do not have a third category. So there are these cases in real life where doctors cannot tell, to my knowledge. And it would be unlikely even for definitions within political ideological groups for definitions to be the same. There's a theory about ribs and roles in Creation apparently that captures as what we do not think is a fundamental characteristic, but is also not observed, a missing rib that held for a duration. But the most important thing about definition is the definition of definition itself. This should be thought of as 'adding definition' to a picture that is unclear. The dictionary definition is part of that maybe, the specialist one another, different individual or professional perspectives may add more, observation and the state of knowledge in a civilisation or even a group might also affect it. And what you are looking to use the definition for matters too. If we want to define a woman for the purposes of catching a criminal as they run from police, it is sufficient to have a sense they may run in a particular way due to hip formation, they might have visible breasts, long hair, dress in a way. What is is knowing the chromosome form on scene, when there's no way of determining that whilst they run. It is sufficient to use one definition for the purposes of the chase. Another in a court room, if necessary, when you have done tests to meet a stricter criteria. I have not heard anyone do for this purpose, presumably because we have a general sense of if someone is a woman or because we just go with whatever is on the birth certificate without further question. Defining an atom at primary school is different from defining it at CERN. Neither wrong, but less precision. If the judgment is around reproductive facility that aspect of definition is more important in being denied fertility treatment than if it is about bullying at work, perhaps. I don't know. Think 'definition' as 'high definition' and how you resolve the details on a TV, and which details matter depends, almost always, on the thing you need to look at.

An interesting fact, which I encourage anyone to look up, is that the word 'man' was used for a long time to mean both what we today call a man and a woman. It did not mean a male person. It just meant a person. 'The word 'waer-mann' later came to referred to a male parson until, about 1300 CE, it eventually became 'man'. Similarly the word 'wif-mann' was used ant it too changed and became woman, and the first part of the word 'wif' became 'wife', which for some time referred to a woman until it came to mean the spouse of a male person.'The argument that a woman is a person who is not a man is nonsense if one is looking for a definition. In the past a 'person who is not a man' would have meant, a person who is not a person.'That might explain a lot about the difficult personal and legal lives of women throughout the ages.'What for me is most interesting is that Judge Jackson could have told an undetectable lie in her answer, and given a definition that Sen. Blackburn would have found pleasing and acceptable. It would have sufficed for the purposes of the hearing in that it would have neutered the question, so to speak. Judge Jackson could then go on to ignore whatever definition she gave to placate Sen. Blackburn and gotten on with the rest of her life. 'She didn't lie, she didn't neuter the question or placate the Republican Senators. She told it as she saw it. 'The appeal to definition (also known as the argument from dictionary) is a logical fallacy that occurs when someone’s argument is based, in a problematic manner, on the definition of a certain term as it appears in a dictionary or a similar source.''The main problem with such arguments is that dictionaries are descriptive in nature, rather than prescriptive, meaning that they attempt to describe how people use the language, rather than instruct them how to do so in a definitive manner.''Accordingly, dictionary definitions don’t always reflect the meaning of words as they’re used by people in reality. This can happen for various reasons, such as that the dictionary definition doesn’t list all the connotations of a word, or that the dictionary definition doesn’t capture the new meaning of a word that has been recently turned into slang.''Furthermore, another notable problem with appeals to definition is that different dictionaries can list different definitions for a given term, and even a single dictionary can have multiple definitions for the same term.''Accordingly, it’s generally fallacious to claim that any single definition is the right one. Furthermore, in many cases, such claims involve fallacious cherry-picking, where people pick the definition that best supports their stance out of the ones available to them, while ignoring others.''Because the appeal to definition is problematic, and because this fallacy is frequently used in discussions on various topics, it’s important to understand it. As such, in the following article you will learn more about the appeal to definition, and see how you can respond to people who use it.'

What he doesn't understand is that judges are there to examine evidence and consider arguments, not make pronunciations absent of nothing. To understand the definition of 'woman' you must understand the basics of gender. To make it easy, gender is not the body parts that define your sex. The vagina and penis do not determine your gender. Gender is the role a person plays in society. And that inherently is defined by a person's culture. For instance, in India they recognize three genders culturally. Man, woman and a third gender group called Hirjas, comprised of transgender,  eunuchs and intersex people. Traditionally, many in the Hirja community dress up with glitter and makeup and go to events like a marriage or birth to lighten the mood and bless those in attendance. They use their status to make money on the streets by offering blessings or curses. In Hinduism, they are recognized as people who have the ability to bless or curse you. They are revered but also feared. That is a gender role. That is what society expects of them. ''Now, back to the definition of a woman. Woman is traditionally known in America to be person who bears children and takes care of the household. The fact that a woman's role has changed rapidly in this country, working jobs and taking over a man's role, means it is harder to define what woman means legally. David didn't want to go into that obviously because this guy wasn't trying to have an honest debate and it's obvious he's taken very little, if any, time to actually read the scientific studies on gender. It's not David's job to teach him these things and frankly, it's tiring having these conversations with people who have zero interest in reality or science. Gender is a role, not sexual organs. Therefore, woman is a role in society and can't easily be defined because having a vagina doesn't automatically mean you fit that role in society (bearing children etc.)

I'm a liberal... having said that, what have we come to that we can't even define what a man and a woman are?  If you are being honest, you would have to admit that it is kind of weird.  So why has this happened.  Because we now have a lot of people who are making up their own definitions of what they are.  Unless you are born without any genitalia or with both, then you are either a man or a woman.  If you have female reproductive organs, then you are a woman.  What if they were removed for some reason?  Well, there are always going to be rare instances that don't fit the mold.  We have to take them as they come and make reasonable and logical allowances.  If you are a man crossdressing as a woman, you are still a man.  You can have a sex change like Bruce Jenner and I am fine with allowing him to now classify as a female.  So what we have is a base definition based on genitalia at birth and then occasional circumstances that we have to make allowances for.  So what happens when a man has a sex change and becomes a woman and he wants to compete against other women in a contact sport?  First of all, how often does this even come up?  It is not exactly a huge problem but it also depends on the type of sport.  Wrestling can be problematic but basketball and baseball, sounds fine to me.  What is happening in our society is that there are a lot of new ways of thinking and being that are clashing with the old ways.  There are valid points to be made on both sides.  It should not be all one thing or all another.  There has to be compromise and it may not always go your way.  But compromise and reasonable solutions to our problems is not on the table right now.  Everyone is in their corner snarling at the other side, and this narrative sells well for the media, better than peaceful solutions.  Who wants to hear about that?  We're more interested in hearing about conflict.

None of these stories playing out in the world are real.  Yet we all still like to be a part of one side or another.  There are no sides, just made up stories.  We are all in this 'experiment' together yet need to be right above someone else.  Working together as a collective for all living beings is where we could be right now!  We are not alone but we are shunned (but highly loved) as a race because we are destructive and unconditional love isn't in play!  Oh well, maybe in another 200 years we will be welcomed as a race of unconditional beings of love and not seen as a  reactive, war mongering bratty race who hurt with words and kill with weapons!!!????

As a philosophy teacher, I can honestly say that the idea that the judgment of Merriam-Webster exhausts the meaning of words is a common display of ignorance - though I'm never surprised to hear it from the 'science-loving' essentialists on the right. Words are always defined by fallible human beings. The whole idea of dictionaries and encyclopedias has been criticized from its MODERN inception for just that reason. Granting greater authority to publishing companies than, say, philosophers, poets, artists, or even just the culture at large is a relatively recent historical idea borne out of this rigid essentialism which the right has come to embody. Any philosopher worth his or her salt, from Plato to Heidegger, is preoccupied with the experiential meaning of words, not with what absolutists prescribe. '         I'd recommend to David that he press further on this idea of defining 'Woman.' Ask these people how they define it. You will be surprised to find that when pushed on such questions, they often become much less sure of themselves. For example, I haven't met many people who want to argue that gender is 100% defined by one's anatomy, and yet the essentialism quickly starts to crumble once you start trying to combine non-physical traits into a genetic essence.

I reviewed the video word by word, and I notice that Michael never states his definition of a woman. He states what he calls 'The old definition', and as a person that can bear children, and produce eggs. But he never states that this is his definition. I think it would be safe to assume it is his definition, but I won't do that because he didn't say it was. But let's look at why that definition isn't correct because it excludes people that we all know are women. There are many women that don't produce eggs, and are incapable of bearing children. Where do they go? And this goes for every single definition of a woman that anyone can make. We all have our own personal definitions of what a woman is. For me, a woman is any person that claims membership of that group exclusively, and accepts the responsibilities, and disadvantages inherit with that role, alongside the other members of the group. This does not mean that they can't work alongside their group members to alleviate disadvantages, but they may take no action that alleviates those disadvantages for them alone. To do so would place them outside of the group. Even this very broad definition would still exclude some people that I know are women, but it is as close as my small brain can come to an all inclusive one.
